title: The Third Order
html:
Not too long after, Cyrus and I stumble upon a local bar, where the lively atmosphere beckons us inside. Seated around a table, along with the fresh new clothes, it feels as if I’m fully blended in with the locals here.

Cyrus hands me a cup, and it looks like the content inside is alcoholic. I hesitate a bit; it's been a while since my last drink, and I'm not sure how quickly it might affect me.

“Just one.” Cyrus said as if he understood.

“Alright.” I grabbed the drink.

“Sorry for the wait.”

Beside us, a man with glasses and slightly long, iris-purple hair takes a seat. Behind those lenses gleams a pair of violet eyes, sharp and crystalline like amethyst, radiating intellect. His attire mirrors Cyrus’s—blue and white garments adorned with elegant golden embroidery, telling a quiet story of nobility and craftsmanship.

“So… who do we have here?” the man asked, his tone smooth and inquisitive.

“This is Vincas,” Cyrus said, rising to his feet. “Vincas, meet Xenon—the friend I mentioned earlier.”

“Nice to meet you, Vincas,” Xenon greeted, offering his hand.

“Likewise,” I replied, standing up to shake it.

“Alright,” Cyrus exhaled, his tone shifting to something more solemn.

He pauses, waiting for the right moment. “Let’s get started.”

He draws a deeper breath and speaks the words with quiet weight. “He’s one of us, Xenon.”

“…”

Xenon goes still.

“He’s not from this world.” Cyrus added, his voice dropping to a whisper.

A moment passes, and then Xenon’s eyes widen in sudden realization. The reaction is instant—and genuine.

Cyrus glances over and grins. “We’re not the only ones. There are more of us out there. And some more… might even be on their way. Isn’t that exciting?”

“Yes. That fact alone has already made my day,” Xenon said, his eyes still gleaming with intrigue. “So, Vincas—how did you arrive here?”

“Straight to the point, as always, huh?” Cyrus teased, raising an eyebrow.

“Time won’t wait.” Xenon replied with a faint smile.

“I’m… not entirely sure,” I said. “I just opened my eyes and found myself in this world.”

“What were you doing before that?” Xenon pressed gently.

“I… can’t remember.”

“Vincas has trouble recalling anything from his previous world,” Cyrus interjected. “It seems like the teleportation caused some sort of memory loss.”

“Interesting…” Xenon mused, tapping his fingers together. Then he suddenly pauses. “Wait—you said his previous world. Why not just say Earth?”

“Because,” Cyrus answered, “he’s not from Earth.”

There is a brief silence before Xenon nods slowly, the wheels already turning behind his eyes. “I see. If Valhalla is a separate world from Earth, then it shouldn’t be surprising that other worlds exist as well.”

I take the chance to ask what has been lingering in my mind. “I’ve been curious—how did both of you end up here?”

“Xenon was teleported here, just like you. As for me… I died and was reincarnated into this world. Both of us arrived after our deaths in the old one.” Cyrus answered.

“Are you able to describe what your other world was like?” Xenon asked, curiosity glinting behind his glasses.

I shake my head. “No. Every time I try to think about my previous life, all I see is a blank void… and then a sharp pain shoots straight through my head.”

The two of them fall silent. For a few moments, they simply watch me—either trying to understand what I just said, or silently searching for an explanation behind the phenomenon.

“How did things go for you two when you first arrived here?” I asked, shifting the topic.

“I had it easy,” Cyrus replied, folding his arms with a relaxed smile. “I was reincarnated as a child prodigy into one of the five noble houses. Honestly, a lot of things were handed to me on a silver plate. I probably don’t have many struggles to share.”

“Child prodigy… really?” Xenon shot him a flat look.

“Self-proclaimed.” Cyrus added with a grin.

“I had it a little rougher,” Xenon said, ignoring the jab and turning to me. “When I woke up, the first thing I saw was a dark room, a fallen stool, and a bundle of torn clothes tied into a noose on the floor.”

This setup…

“I’m assuming the previous owner of this body attempted suicide,” he continued calmly. “Maybe he failed and knocked himself out. Maybe he succeeded, and I just… took over what was left. Either way, I ended up here.”

“Were you ever able to find out why he did it?”

He nods. “He—now I—was born into a noble family as well, like Cyrus. It’s just speculation, but it seems this body had never resonated with Aetherion. Being a noble and failing to meet expectations must’ve driven him to despair. The pressure was too much.”

His voice is detached—almost like he’s recounting someone else’s tale. In a way, I suppose he is.

“Don’t fall for his act,” Cyrus cut in, half-chuckling. “Since then, he’s already managed to resonate with Aetherion and even became a full-fledged Templar of the Fourth Order. He’s doing just fine now. No pity necessary.”

“Oh…”

From what I’ve observed so far, it is clear that Cyrus and Xenon are close. There is a looseness to the way Cyrus acts around him—a familiarity I haven’t seen him show with anyone else.

“Anyway,” I said, recalling something that had caught my attention earlier. “Cyrus, when we entered through the gate, you showed the guards a kind of medallion. What was that?”

“Oh… this?” Cyrus reached into his coat and pulled it out.

Now that I have a proper look, the medallion is more intricate than I expected. Finely crafted from silver and suspended from a thick chain, it bore the symbol of a towering spire surrounded by rays of light, all enclosed within a perfect circle. There was a sense of symmetry and balance to the design—simple, yet commanding.

“Yes. That,” I nodded. “What is it?”

“You can think of it as an identity card—a very privileged one, in fact,” Cyrus replied.

“The medallion proves that he’s a Resonated,” Xenon added, “someone who’s received a Soulforge. It’s a universally recognized item across the Bastions. With it, a Resonator can freely travel between strongholds.”

“You’ll get one soon too,” Cyrus said with a smile.

“Wait—he’s joining the Order?” Xenon asked, looking at me in surprise, then back at Cyrus. “Don’t tell me you’ve already roped him in.”

“Yes,” Cyrus smirked. “And don’t you dare try to steal him away. First come, first served. Vincas has already agreed.”

“Are you sure?” Xenon turned to me, concern etched into his features. “Becoming a Resonator under an Order isn’t something to take lightly.”

“What’s there to think about?” Cyrus cut in, waving his hand dismissively. “Unlike us, he doesn’t have a home here yet. If he becomes a Templar—which, I believe, he certainly can—he’ll be given proper accommodations and income. That alone gives him a foundation to rebuild his life. And on top of that, he gains status—something vital if he wants to make a place for himself in this world.”

“Yes, I know,” Xenon said, frowning. “But you left out the part where he’ll be fighting Hellspawns the moment he joins the Order. That’s not something you can just gloss over. It comes with the risk of death, Cyrus. This isn’t a decision to push on someone.”

“Being a Resonator is the most sought-after role in this world,” Cyrus argued. “It’s about more than just risk. We protect lives. We carry the will of humanity. We were all given a second chance in this world and especially with gifts like ours, why shouldn’t we use them to live fully?”

“But…”

“Don’t worry, Xenon. I’m aware of the risks.”

“Are you sure about this, Vincas?” Xenon asked again, his voice tinged with concern. “If it’s just shelter and a way to survive that you’re looking for, we have other ways to help you. Becoming a recognised Resonator means taking on a burden. You carry responsibility, and your life could be on the line at any moment.”

“It’s okay,” I said with calm certainty. “I want to join the Order.”

I understand his concern—really, I do. But if all I want is to survive, I may as well have stayed who I was before. That life—safe, ordinary, stagnant—is the very thing I no longer want. I’ve been given a second chance in this world, and with it, a gift unlike any other. If I don’t take this opportunity, I will only betray that chance and fall back into the same emptiness.

Xenon looks at me for a moment longer, then nods slowly, seemingly satisfied with my resolve.

Maybe I still carry regrets. Maybe I haven’t forgiven myself entirely. But what’s the use in mourning what’s already lost? The only thing that matters now is how I move forward—with those regrets, not in spite of them.

In the echoes of my failures, I find the will to redeem myself. For every life I couldn’t protect, I’ll save twice as many. For every soul I couldn’t reach, I’ll become a shield for countless others.

Wait… what am I talking about?

Why do I want to redeem myself?

!!!

“Argh—” A sharp pain stabbed through the back of my head like a hot needle.

“Are you alright?” Cyrus and Xenon spoke at once, both instantly on alert.

“Yeah… I’m fine,” I said, rubbing the side of my head. “Something about my past just… surfaced out of nowhere.”

“I see.” Xenon exhaled softly, as if letting go of a breath he didn’t realise he was holding.

“Tomorrow morning, I’ll take you to register for the trial,” Cyrus said.

“Trial? What do you mean by that?”

“It’s a trial by combat,” he explained. “A basic test to determine whether you’ve got the ability to join the Order.”

“Shouldn’t I have more time to prepare for something like that?” I asked, a little anxious.

“You won’t need it. I’ve seen you fight—you’re more than ready,” Cyrus said confidently.

“Okay…” I nodded.

“I know you still have a lot of questions,” Xenon said gently. “So don’t hesitate to ask. We’re always here to help.”

“There’s just so much to learn,” I admitted. “I really appreciate everything—truly. From both of you.”

“You’re welcome,” Cyrus replied with a warm grin. “You and Xenon are the only ones I know who came from another world. It’s been nearly a decade since I met him. I’m honestly glad there’s someone else now.”

Cyrus’s words resonate in a way I haven’t expected.

“He’s right,” Xenon added, his voice calm and sincere. “In this estranged world, we’re all we’ve got.”

!!!

Suddenly, a deafening explosion rips through the air outside, shaking the ground beneath us. The walls of the bar tremble, glasses shatter, and for a moment, the warmth of laughter and conversation is replaced by the chilling sound of panicked screams.

Everyone shoots to their feet. Cyrus, Xenon, and I are no exception. We rush outside, instincts guiding our bodies before thought can catch up.

Cyrus is the first to burst through the doors—and then he freezes.

His voice comes out low and shaken. “How… in the world…”

Xenon and I follow, only to be struck silent by the sight above us.

There, looming in the sky like some divine punishment, floats a colossal obsidian pillar, impossibly suspended above the heart of the Bastion. Arcs of black lightning crackles around it. A deep hum reverberates through the air, like a heartbeat from another world.

“A Hellsgate?!” Cyrus shouted, disbelief etched across his face. “Why is it here?!”

“That shouldn’t be possible,” Xenon added, his voice tight. “There’s no record of one ever appearing within a Bastion. They only show up in the wilds—or at the borders at worst…”

“No time to figure it out.” Cyrus’s voice snapped back into command. “We move. Now.”

There is no need for further words. We all nod and sprint forward, the cobblestone streets already erupting in chaos around us—guards rallying, citizens running, warning horns blaring in rising urgency.

My heartbeat thunders with every step. The trial I thought I’d be facing this morning had just turned into something far greater—and far deadlier.

Screams echo down the alleys. Fires lick the rooftops. The stench of burning wood mixes with blood and something far fouler—something not of this world.

Hellspawns swarm the streets—grotesque, pitch-black creatures that twist and pulse like shadows given flesh. They maul anything in their path. Across the street, one of them tears a man in half with a single swipe.

Cyrus rises into the air, his cape fluttering like a banner of hope against the horror. With a wave of his hand, dozens of glowing ethereal spears materialise around him. Then, he launches them—each one piercing through the air before impaling the largest Hellspawns in a radiant burst of light and force.

A desperate cry rises above the chaos.

“Help!”

A woman, pinned beneath a collapsed beam, clutches her crying child tightly. Her leg is twisted at a sickening angle.

Before I can move, a rift tears through space beside her, and from it steps Xenon, his eyes cold with focus. He gently reaches out, pulls them both into the swirling portal, and vanishes—only to appear moments later across the street, doing the same for another panicked group.

He moves like a ghost, blinking from one place to the next.

I clench my hand around a broken stick—then let my instinct take over. A surge of dark energy well up within me, coating the makeshift weapon in a jagged black sheen.

No more hesitation. I charge.

With every swing, the dark-coated weapon proves effective against the Hellspawns. The soldiers, emboldened by our presence, begin to regroup. Side by side, we cut a path through the chaos, pushing the monsters back.

We secure the plaza. Blood slicks the stone streets, and bodies—both human and inhuman—lay still in the aftermath. Fires still burn, but the civilians have mostly escaped. For now, this corner of the Bastion is holding.

“Are you alright?” Xenon reappeared beside me, breathing heavily, his coat torn and stained.

“I’m okay,” I panted. “What do we do now?”

“I’m evacuating the rest,” he said, eyes scanning the buildings. “You follow Cyrus’s lead. Tell him I’ll be back right away.”

“Got it.”

He puts a hand on my shoulder before I leave. His grip is firm—almost desperate.

“I’m sorry to ask for your help so soon, Vincas. I know it’s selfish to drag you into this right after everything…”

“It’s okay,” I interrupted, locking eyes with him. “I want to fight.”

For a second, his stern expression softens. Then he gives me a nod—and vanishes once more.

As I turn to find Cyrus, I can hear distant screams again. More Hellspawns are coming.

And this time… they are bigger.

Cyrus then descends beside me, the air around him still crackling faintly with residual energy.

“What’s the situation?” he asked without wasting a breath.

“Xenon’s evacuating civilians. He told me to follow your lead—he’ll be back soon.”

“Good.” He gave a sharp nod. “We’re heading straight for the Hellsgate. My men should already be converging from the east. We’ll be assisting the Third Order.”

“The Third Order?” I echoed.

“They’re the shield of the Bastion. The first responders. If anyone can hold the line while the rest of us arrive, it’s them.” His voice turned firm. “Let’s move.”

We sprint toward the rising pillar of corruption in the distance, where the skies churn black and red, stained by the presence of the open gate. With every step, the city looks more like a war zone—collapsed buildings, scorched streets, twisted metal.

Hellspawns swarm the path ahead—skittering, leaping, shrieking.

We tear through them. Cyrus leads with terrifying grace, weaving through the battlefield like a storm incarnate. He soars into the air, spears manifesting with each motion of his hands, piercing enemies before they even see him coming. His face is unreadable, eyes locked forward with an unwavering intensity.

I follow behind, striking fast and true with my darkened weapon. But no matter how many we fell, there are always more. The ground is slick with blood.

I watched a family torn apart before I could reach them. A soldier screaming as he was dragged into the shadows. The smell, the sounds—it claws at my senses, my stomach twisting.

I force myself to move.

Every scream unanswered. Everybody I failed to save. They burn into my memory. But I keep going. I have to.

Then, ahead of us—an explosion lights the sky in orange. A wave of flame roars down the avenue, engulfing a swarm of Hellspawns in an instant. The fire dances high into the air like a blazing wall.

I flinch, instinctively raising my arm to shield myself. But beside me, Cyrus didn’t even blink. Instead, his eyes widened—his expression breaking into something I haven’t seen yet tonight: relief.

“They’re here…” he whispered. “The Third Order.”

And then—through the flame and smoke—they emerge.

Dozens of silver-armored figures march in perfect formation, their cloaks catching the firelight with a ghostly shimmer. Shields held high, halberds at the ready, they move like a wall—unyielding, unstoppable. Their steps are thunder. Their presence, divine.

They push forward with practiced precision, cutting down any Hellspawn in their path.

For a moment—I forgot the chaos. I forgot the death.

All I could feel was awe.

Hellspawns, one after another, hurl themselves at the soldiers, but the defensive line holds. Their shields resist the onslaught, locking together with practiced precision. Then, a much larger Hellspawn crashes into them, its brute force overwhelming the line. Some soldiers are knocked back, and the beast drops right in front of us.

But it’s already dead—its body engulfed in flames.

We don’t stop. As soon as the soldiers recognise Cyrus, they instinctively part, letting us through without hesitation.

Ahead of us stands a lone figure—a woman, poised with a golden staff in hand. A banner of flame coils from its shaft, dancing wildly in the chaos. She moves like flowing fire, weaving through the battlefield with deadly grace. Every Hellspawn that dares approach her is instantly scorched to ash.

Facing her is a massive, stone-like Hellspawn—its rocky frame resisting her flames with unsettling endurance. Still, the fire continues to grow, intensifying with every second. Despite its hulking build, the creature begins to falter under the heat.

But then I notice something else.

Is it the fire... or something else entirely? The air around her shimmers strangely, warping like a heat haze. I squint, and faintly—just barely—I catch the outline of a shape hidden within the distortion.

It resembles... a monster.
